review_blob: From bottle.  This has everything one expects from a dunkelweizen but to a muted and subconscious degree.  I mean you really have to search for the wonderfully complex aroma and flavor that should be rather pronounced.  That being said, it is crisp and clean without any of the easy trappings that immature brewers attempting the style often fall into.  It tastes and smells like someone mixed a really good dunkelweizen and an APA half and half; making it sessionable but weak.

Aroma of a watermelon Jolly Rancher.  Appearance of watermelon Koolaid.  The flavor has cherry notes mixed with rose petals but is weak and ephemeral.  The palate is clean and crisp.  Overall Im underwelmed.  I want to say it is a refreshing session fruit beer, but I dont think I could handle more than one due to a strange filling quality and a lack of carbonation.

On tap at Maggies in Buckhannon WV.  Rather bland and light but quite typical for the style.  Nice lactic quality, smooth on the palate, flavors of light chestnut.  Nothing harsh, nothing dramatic, nothing over the top, but rather a standard, but very drinkable beverage.
beer_name: Mountain State Miners Daughter Oatmeal Stout

review_blob: I think I strained a nostral trying to pull some aroma off this beer.  What element of fragrance it does possess is like that of a stale and flavorless orange.  If one were to match the flavor you merely need to mix 2 parts Sunny-D with 1 part carbonated water.  The palate is sticky and stale.  There is an aftertaste similar to that which one would receive from eating a pound of the off-white portion of an orange rind.  If I owned a goose, I would rub its nose (or bill) in this beer while saying "come on, Goose, youre better than this".

Pours dark and headless with amber shallows.  The aroma harbors raspberry marshmallows, graham crackers and vanilla.  The flavor is rather dry with vanilla highlights and a subtle smokiness.  I keep searching deeper for substance, but continue to come up empty.  A kind of hollow empty void pervades this beer as though it were longing for the earthy yeast of its breathern.  Overall, seems more like a failed attempt at something bigger rather than what it, at last, is.

Aroma is soapy and slightly sweet with a touch of bubble gum.  Color is dull bronze with a slight haziness.  Flavor would be easier to describe if, in fact, there was any.  There is some bread and hops, but it is watered down with a dishwater dominance.  Palate is sticky and slick like Id just eaten catelope, watermelon or some other cucubit that has no place in a beer.  Overall, I dont know what this beer is trying to accomplish.  If it is to disturb or otherwise confuse or to serve as an example of poor quality or taste then mission accomplished.

I have to agree with the last reviewer (drmatt) in that this is in no way an imperial stout.  Someone goofed.  Perhap "sweet stout" would be a more adequate monaker.  Regardless, aroma is where this baby shines.  Rich robust vanilla and coffee with cinnamon rolls and sweet frosting give this beer a real breakfast appeal.  The head is dense and tan and lingers to the end.  The flavor, unfortunately, falls flat and is too lactic sweet for endulgence.  In fact, it tastes like a flat Mackeson XXX (further evidence for my "sweet stout" claim).  Palate is creamy with some licorice and cough medicine.  All in all, this is pretty good for a Schlafly product, which I generally find to be stale, fake and lackluster.

Ah, the joys of cheap beer.  While others may scoff, I am determined to appreciate these watery gems and to extract as much flavor and understanding as possible.  This "pale lager" ranks lower than most.  Perhaps this is because it is the light rendition of "the champagne of beers" which already has a bad image.  Perhaps it is "the sprarkling wine of beers".  Regardless, it does have some negative qualities, even for the style.  While it does go down smooth, it leaves a "left the bar half buzzed" taste on the palate.  The color is typical and would require a Munsel Color Chart to define other than golden-yellow.  The carbonation is good, the flavor is unique and not unlike the "full bodied" High Life.  Basically, if you just want to drink a few beers while youre tinkering in the garage, this is a cheap and way to do it.

In the realm of standard american light beers, this beverage isnt half bad.  The aroma is pleasant, the appearance is clean, clear, golden and heady.  The flavor harbors less of the undesirable adjunct flavors of its breathern and goes down smooth and clean without the sick and sticky sweetness of bud light and miller lite.  Granted, it is no Burger Classic and it doesnt have the romantic brewing history of the pre-modern styles.  But when placed in the historical context of post-prohabition america and its place in the industrial revolution that followed, one might see that this is a working mans beer.  The beer of coalminers, steelworkers and the back broken sons of immigrant labors that traded their souls to fatcat tycoons and that, broken and sore, laid down a spare penny for a tall, glass of just such a cheap, cold and refreshing elixir.  It is an american beer, with its own marvelous history that does not pale, nay shines, in the light of european piety.  No pomp, no coarse discrimination, but beer in its simplest form.

A wholesome and fresh aroma consisting of smoked salmon and the smell of a deep freeze full of berries and popsicles; just like my great grandmas (no kidding, its a dead ringer).  The flavor and palate are quite watery.  In fact, the porter flavor is really lacking, leaving a salty salmon flaccidity.  I attribute this lack of robust character to the hollow absence of hops and perhaps a stale malt.  Aroma is the only positive.

I just typed a long elaborate comment for this beer.  But, having noticed that the photo didnt match my bottle (no naked chick), I clicked the image for a closer look.  When I went back to my rate, I found my hard work had been erased.  Miffed and nt having the strength to repeat the process, I give you this:  Air freshener aroma; jucy-juice flavor; low carbonation and complacent palate; overall, "yawn".
UPDATED: JAN 3, 2007
UPDATED: JAN 3, 2007

A nice, easy and pale strong ale with a candied fruit aroma, a crisp palate and clean finish.  The color is blonde and the head is pronounced, frothy and persistent.  The flavor holds tart apples above light candied sugar and subtle yeastiness.  Overall,  a very nice balance of subtle characters.  This is certainly a beer to be paired with fine dining or a quick nibbling of cheese.
UPDATED: DEC 23, 2006
beer_name: Harviestoun Old Engine Oil Special Reserve

review_blob: Interesting, but not terribly good.  The flavor is schizo with a dark lager stroke over aled malts.  Perhaps this is the molasses.  Finish is rather rough. The palate is tight and constraining.  Fun, but lacking style and persistence.

The most enchanting thing about Matilda is her fragrance.  It streams easy and effortless through the nostrals, igniting a rhapsody of aromas; cucurbit spices, coriander and earthy esters.  Her tone is copper and honey with a cloudy aire.  Her head, lofty and blonde.  Sugar candy and old-world yeast combine in a malty colaboration, but ends rather hollow; apple pie without the nutmeg.  The finish is were it is most absent.  Close.  It is so close.

On tap at the Big Johnson (not related to the lame t-shirts of the 80s) Doc House in Washington, Missouri.  Deep amber with a light, but creamy froth.  Aroma is light and slightly floral with a warm finish.  The flavor is quite unique in that it has a dry bite, followed by a mellow hoppiness and a well rounded malt resonation.  Palate is light and clean.  This scores an extra point by being a unique rendition of a near cookie cutter style.

Thick and muddy with no head. Pours flat, tastes flat, hell it is flat.  That loses major points but the flavor is so hearty, robust and chewy that it partially redeams itself.  Flavor contains elements of iron, licorice, major hops, cough medicine, bakers chocolate, carob, burnt caramel and hot molasses.  Aroma harbors notes of horse, yes horse, bloody steak and worchestershire sauce (maybe A-1).  Palate is rich with velvet love given the strong flavors and has a biting licorice finish.  Have a few (preferably over several days) before you rate, because it does grow on you.  The drawback, and quite a major defect, is the lack of carbonation.  It really does make this come off as a foul cough syrup. Like I said, its just so damn flavorful.
beer_name: Dark Horse Plead the 5th Imperial Stout

review_blob: Pours medium bodied with a coppery shine and a blond highlighted boldness. Aroma of apples and roses with a touch of cinnamon.  Not a strong aroma but strong enough to enjoy.  Flavor starts very rich, sweet, malty and refined then quickly turns sour and watery.  Probably the strangest and most conspicuously transformation my buds have witnessed.  In this dichotomy of flavor is raspberry, rye, rich malt and twangy hops. The alcohol lies dormant to the procession such that I find it hard to believe the 10% claimed.  Overall, not really wild about this one, though quite interesting.  I bought a single and dont suggest anyone buy the sixer until you have sampled some.  The wheat makes it interesting, but leads to an annoying twang.

Whatever, Three Floyds.  Basically a session ale with a hop overlay.  Pours red and with little head.  Aroma is 90% grapefruit hops, 5% maple and 5% standard malt.  Flavor is hoppy with a slight sweetness.  I wish I could find more deScriptive terms, but it more a lack of flavor than vocabulary.  Another tragic attempt to artificially inflate the flavor of a beer with sleezy hops.  This is not an Irish Ale, it is an IPA, and a sub-par one at that.  It leaves me pondering, what would this beer be without hype?

Pours dark and reddish with nice lacing. Aroma is pine resin and very fortelling of the acridity ahead.  Not much else. Flavor is rough, raw and quite raunchy followed by sickening sweet.  I mean teeth rotting, sugar coma sweet.  This is not a Barley Wine! It is a super sweet double IPA. I have an extra bottle aging that Ill re-rate onced it has aged say.......50years. I am not impressed and I am saddened that something so putridly wrong is so highly rated.  I guess I just dont get it.

Pours beautifully clear with a rich clover honey color.  Arom is honey scented with hints of rain and just a touch of smooth crisp hops.  Flavor is richly malty with earth, more honey and a nice hoppy buzz to the palate.  Overall, clean, fresh, drippingly delicious, robust and certainly a top notch Maibock.  Spring has arrived. Bring on the beers.

2002: Pours heavy, effervescent and cool into the glass where it sits smuggly and says with a hint of piety " I, good sir, have aged to perfection".  Its white stubble of head gives proof to the potion as does the candy caramel vapor of its breath, so heavily ladden with meadow hay, wildflowers and time.  Now as this ruby-auburn and polished walnut pool is hoisted to my anticipating lips, I taste.  All acridity, hops and alcohol lie as a hound upon the hearth of aged and masterful malts: present and appreciated but not alerted.  The flavor oozes earthy tones and nutty notes as the complexity of apple rind and raisins blend, dance and twirl upon the tongue like jazz; class and rhythm.
Basically a beefy amber ale.  Dark chestnut and slightly hazy.  Aroma of tea and bananna bread/walnuts.  Flavor is flacidly malty and kind of plain.  Overall, enjoy your retirement.

Pours as black as stout with a palamino head.  Aroma is light and difficult to detect, but with subtle smokiness and deep alcohol tones.  Flavor is very raw and malty with little complexity and a light molasses/sorgham quality.  Some chocolate notes peak through.  Hops are nearly undetectable.  Palate is smooth and rather undefined.  Overall, raw and plain.

Pale brown/honey in color.  Aroma is apple and maple syrup with heavy and ripe malts.  Flavor is rich and hoppy with sweet maple tones and grape-caramel highlights.  Hops is crisp, yet mellow and mature.  Truly a malted champion with excellent hoppy crisp palate.  The appearance is a bit murky and muddled.  Very nice, overall.

Pours on the light side with large bubbles that dissipate quickly.  Aroma of toffee and minimal soy.  Flavor is bitterish with light coffee and an unripe grape element.  The palate is clean and easy.  Overall, a very drinkable and unassuming porter.

Pours dark and with minimal, quickly diminishing head.  Aroma is vineous and sweet with a hint of silage.  Flavor is flat, sweet, molasses-filled but lacking the prune/raisin goodness of a solid doppelbock.  Raw and underdeveloped with no deep complexity.  Otherwise, reasonably good.  Certainly has the taste of a Weihenstephan beer.

A raw pumpkin flavor.  Aroma is light and butterscotchy.  Flavor is malty and floral with a nice light hop spice.  Copper-red with nice medium "to the edge" froth.  Almost a flat cola flavor or artificial caramel.  Overall, very pleasant.  I could drink a tall glass of this.

Pours black with a hint of chestnut. Aroma is dark and lightly fruity. Head is minimal. A sweet licorice looms behind dark malt aromas. Flavor is savory and loaded, but clean and heavy with over-ripe fruits (passion and kiwi). Light smokiness and licorice present but thicker flavor than the fluid concentration would elude to.  Palate is clean. Probably a very true rendition of the style but beaten down by the more extreme recipes fancied by the general. I respect this beverage as a solid, complex and worth beverage, but I must admit I am enticed by more potent offerings.

The brown-red color of pure cherry juice and a light fizz atop. The aroma is cherry, vineous and sweet emissions with a hint of anticeptic. Flavor is tart with aged, ripe, seductive cherries. Contagious.....salacious.....outrageous!! A thick smooth maltiness that coats and numbs the mouth. The flavor is simple enough, while the palate is the real champion here. The sweetness is subtle yet very well balanced with the tart. Really a fine beverage and well worth the cash, stash and anticipation.

Magnificent color and clarity, with a copper-gold shimmer. Apple juice aroma with a hint of yeasty effluence. Flavor is honey comb and subdued with some buttery quench.  Palate is light and quite shallow. Overall, quite tasty and a pleasureable drink, but the light candy simplicity falls short of more complex concoctions.

Despite claims, this beer breaks no styles and certainly has no distinct flavor.  It is jus another disappointing IPA in a Trojan bottle. No complexity, no charm, just bland malt and overloaded hops. Pours dark and polluted with floaties. Aroma is hoppy. Flavor is hoppy. Yawn.

Im shocked at the low rating of what I find to be a very solid amber ale. Rich malty originality with a hop charge. Warm, spicy and fresh. A classy beverage that doesnt need to show off with a crazy label, name, recipe or inflated price. Bottomline, quality for the sake of quality. A very nice, clean and savory beverage.

Pours dark with minimal head. Aroma is raspberry and cocoa as the bottle says. Flavor is sourish with a hint of chocolate. The porter element is weak and unsavory. Overall, the sour taint is too much. Rhubarb is certainly a fitting deScription. I expected better from sprecher. A let down.

Eisbock darkness with minimal head and apple carbonation. Aroma of Kahlua, vanilla, prunes and sweet malty heaven. Flavor is sweetish, chewy and vanilla spiced. Raisins, grapes, and alcohol with a smooth palate. Not quite as complex or flavorful as Kulmbacher, but very good.

Dark amber with a hint of orange color. Aroma is very yeasty and sweet with butterscotch and apple notes. Carbonation is on the weak end of average. Flavor is stark, rich and lucious. Sweet yeasty notes with heavy malts and complex flavors. Palate is strong on the booze but clean and candy tongued. Overall, very tasty and smooth. Me like.

2004: Barely a barley wine with 57% wheat, but delicious none the less. It certainly tastes wheaty with loads of bananna and clove yeastiness. The malt is dry and smooth and clean. The flavor is rich yet mellow and easy. Bananna esters dominate and a hop bitterness seals the deal. Pours cloudy and light brown. Overall, very nice and very unique. Reminds me of Franziskaner dunkle-weiss.
beer_name: Two Brothers Bare Tree Weiss Wine (2002 and later)

review_blob: UPDATED: JAN 31, 2005

2002: Served piping hot. Like tart cherry pie in a glass. Warm, slightly sweet and slightly tart. Aroma is very lambic with yeast roughness, a spicy element and a twist of cherry. Pours fizzy. Smooth on the tongue and easy on the palate. Tastes a bit watered down. Quite pleasing and well worth the try. Actually better as it cools (cant say that about very  many beers).

Quite hoppy with grapefruit potency. Head ephemeral and light with light lacing. Slightly cloudy. Malts are mellow and blend well with the hops. Full bodied malts and decent flavor but I cant get past the hops. Not impressed.

Like a cross between a barley wine and a brown ale. Aroma is candy corn with a touch of alcohol. The color is deep chestnut with amber shallows. Flavor is rich and creamy but subdued. Alcohol is muted and no bitterness to speak of but a nice hop element. Overall, very interesting, unique and delicious.
Great bubblegum aroma off a semi-cloudy fluid. Deep amber color. Flavor is light hops, slight sourness, malt dominance and a clean yet bitter finish. Overall, pretty good and very drinkable.

Pours rich and auburn with minimal head. A barley wine nose with butterscotch and jasmine highlights. The flavor is hoppy and a tad acrid. A strong green tea element that ends bitter. Overall, quite interesting. The alcohol doesnt dominate, yet it is certainly present.

After drinking a case of this over the last several months, I cant believe I havent rated it. Nice blood and chrome aroma with complexities of soy sauce, liquid smoke and vanilla extract. Flavor is licorice, vanilla bean, burnt sugar, kettle corn and sizzling steak. Appearence is black with luciously dark brown shallows. It warms the face and esophagus. Palate is easy and clean yet lingering with sweet char and potent hoppy excellence. One of my favorites.

Cloudy and tan with a touch of orange. Minimal head and medium high carbonation. The aroma is spicy and ladden with alcohol, sweet yeast and roasted honey. Golden flavors touched by the sun. Apple, summer, morning dew and the consciousness of youth. Palate is rich and satisfying. Overall, very good, quite complex and certainly flavorful. Not really an attractive looking beer.

Sweet and malty to the extreme max. Very much like the unfermented carbonated malt beverages that are drank like soda in africa and south america.  But beyond the malt is a dopplebock grapyness and a grapefruit cereal quality (which is malted cereal). Very different than other baltics Ive tried. Virtually no hops detected and little carbonation. Lighter than most porters. Anyway, very interesting and quite good. Give yourself a few days without sugar, to recover.

Flavored with mushrooms. No really, I can taste them. Certainly a wild flavor and though I am spatially and temporally foreign to the style, I am pleased at the progress beers have made over the centuries. That being said, The aroma is very nut and honey cheerios with an earthy musk. Honey and roses come through in the flavor with sweetness, chammomile and herbs (corriander?). Appearence is brown and cloudy with some floaties. Very interesting. Gotta respect the ancestors. Im a little peaved that they write up a deal about the last recipe of traditional brews and how great and traditional this beer is, then lightly elude to the fact that they changed the recipe to be darker and more flavorful. Thats just shady.

Ah, yes. The flavor of stouts befor Id tasted real quality. Not that this is bad, but in every quality I find it to be too refined.  Pours black, but light and pale in shallows.  Flavor is hazelnut, vanilla extract and a subtle smokiness.  Aroma is one dimensional malt and a subtle alcohol presence. Palate is weak. Overall, drinkable, but sub-standard.
